data.question: What is the key challenge that the six new hybrid ultramicroporous materials (HUMs) reported in this study aim to address?
data.answer: The six new HUMs aim to address the trade-off between selectivity and adsorption capacity that has been a major roadblock for reducing the energy footprint of gas separation technologies, especially for C2H2/CO2 separation.

data.question: Which HUM exhibited the best C2H2/CO2 separation performance in this study?
data.answer: SIFSIX-21-Ni outperformed all other sorbents, exhibiting a benchmark separation selectivity of 27.7 and high C2H2 adsorption capacity of 4 mmol路g鈭?.

data.question: What are the two key features of HUMs that are thought to enhance selective gas binding?
data.answer: The two key features of HUMs that enhance selective binding are: 1) narrow pore sizes and 2) pore surfaces/walls offering strong electrostatics.

data.question: How many HUMs studied in this work were able to break the trade-off between high adsorption capacity 鈮?.5 mmol路g鈭? and high separation selectivity 鈮? for C2H2/CO2 separation?
data.answer: Four of the HUMs - SIFSIX-21-Ni, NbOFFIVE-3-Ni, TIFSIX-4-Cu, and NbOFFIVE-3-Cu - were able to break the trade-off, exhibiting adsorption capacities 鈮?.5 mmol路g鈭? and separation selectivities 鈮? for C2H2/CO2 separation.

data.question: What techniques were used to probe the binding sites of C2H2 and CO2 in the best performing HUMs?
data.answer: In situ infrared (IR) spectroscopy measurements were performed on NbOFFIVE-3-Cu and SIFSIX-21-Ni to probe the binding sites of C2H2 and CO2. Solid-state NMR spectroscopy was also used to investigate the behavior of 13CO2 and C2D2 adsorbed in NbOFFIVE-3-Cu.

data.question: What is the significance of the difference in isosteric heats of adsorption between C2H2 and CO2, denoted as 螖Qst(C2H2/CO2)?
data.answer: The difference in isosteric heats of adsorption between C2H2 and CO2, 螖Qst(C2H2/CO2), reflects the relative thermodynamic preference of the sorbents for C2H2 over CO2. A higher 螖Qst(C2H2/CO2) value indicates a stronger affinity for C2H2 compared to CO2.

data.question: Why is it important to study the performance of sorbents for C2H2/CO2 separation under dynamic conditions, such as in dynamic column breakthrough (DCB) experiments?
data.answer: Studying sorbent performance under dynamic conditions like DCB experiments is important because calculating separation performance from single-component C2H2 and CO2 isotherms tends to overestimate the actual separation ability. DCB experiments provide a more realistic assessment of how the sorbents will perform in real-world separation processes.

data.question: How does the modularity of HUMs enable fine-tuning of their pore size and chemistry for enhanced gas separation performance?
data.answer: The modularity of HUMs allows for crystal engineering-driven control of pore size and chemistry by varying the organic linker ligands, inorganic pillar ligands, and metal cations used to construct the frameworks. This enables systematic optimization of the HUM structure and properties for specific gas separation applications.

data.question: Based on the IR and NMR spectroscopy results, what interactions are thought to be responsible for the stronger binding of C2H2 compared to CO2 in the HUMs?
data.answer: The IR and NMR results suggest that C2H2 forms stronger interactions with the HUMs, including hydrogen bonding interactions via the acidic C-H groups, compared to CO2. The spectroscopic data shows evidence of multiple strong C2H2 binding sites, while CO2 appears to interact more weakly with the frameworks.

data.question: Why is it advantageous for the HUMs to exhibit weak CO2 binding in addition to strong C2H2 affinity for achieving high C2H2/CO2 selectivity?
data.answer: Weak CO2 binding in the HUMs is advantageous because it means CO2 will be more easily displaced by C2H2 and rapidly eluted from the sorbent bed during separation processes. The combination of strong C2H2 affinity and weak CO2 interactions leads to a large difference in binding strength, 螖Qst(C2H2/CO2), which is key for achieving high C2H2/CO2 selectivity.

data.question: True or False: The HUMs reported in this study require high temperatures (>400 K) to activate the unsaturated metal centers that drive selective C2H2 binding.
data.answer: False. The HUMs in this study only require heating to 333 K for activation and sorbent regeneration, which is an advantage over other C2H2-selective sorbents like UTSA-74a that require high temperature activation at 473 K.

data.question: True or False: IAST calculations based on single-component C2H2 and CO2 isotherms provide an accurate prediction of real-world separation performance for the HUMs.
data.answer: False. The authors state that IAST calculations tend to overestimate separation performance compared to actual mixed-gas separation under dynamic conditions. DCB experiments are needed to get a more realistic assessment of separation ability.

data.question: True or False: All six HUMs studied exhibited higher C2H2 uptake than CO2 uptake at 298 K and 1 bar pressure.
data.answer: True. The single-component isotherms showed that all six HUMs had C2H2 uptakes greater than 3.5 mmol路g鈭? at 298 K and 1 bar, while the CO2 uptakes under the same conditions were less than 2.0 mmol路g鈭?.

data.question: True or False: The in situ PXRD measurements revealed significant structural changes in SIFSIX-21-Ni and SIFSIX-21-Cu during C2H2 adsorption up to 1 bar pressure.
data.answer: False. The in situ PXRD measurements showed no significant changes in the PXRD patterns of SIFSIX-21-Ni and SIFSIX-21-Cu with C2H2 loading up to 1 bar, indicating only subtle structural changes occur during C2H2 adsorption.

data.question: True or False: The solid-state NMR results suggest that CO2 binds more strongly than C2H2 in the NbOFFIVE-3-Cu framework.
data.answer: False. The solid-state NMR spectra indicate that NbOFFIVE-3-Cu has a higher affinity for C2D2 than 13CO2 under the same loading conditions, consistent with the stronger binding of C2H2 over CO2 observed from other characterization techniques.

data.question: True or False: The single-crystal X-ray diffraction studies revealed that SIFSIX-21-Ni, TIFSIX-4-Ni, SIFSIX-21-Cu, and TIFSIX-4-Cu all adopt different framework topologies.
data.answer: False. The single-crystal X-ray diffraction results showed that SIFSIX-21-Ni, TIFSIX-4-Ni, SIFSIX-21-Cu, and TIFSIX-4-Cu are isostructural and all crystallize as pcu topology networks in the orthorhombic space group Pnna.

data.question: True or False: The accelerated stability tests demonstrated that all six HUMs exhibit excellent stability after exposure to high humidity conditions.
data.answer: False. The accelerated stability tests revealed that while NbOFFIVE-3-Ni, SIFSIX-21-Cu, TIFSIX-4-Cu, and NbOFFIVE-3-Cu maintained excellent stability, SIFSIX-21-Ni and TIFSIX-4-Ni underwent a phase change after exposure to 75% relative humidity at 313 K.
